content.intro:
Under the protection of Notre-Dame de Fourvière, nestled between the Rhône and the Saône rivers, and just a few hours from the Alps and the Mediterranean, this luminary city is an invitation to discover centuries of history and happen upon its many riches as you walk and explore.

Lyon has been part of a tumultuous history that has thus far spanned more than 2,000 years. The pride of the Renaissance, you simply need to visit Old Lyon to get a feel for all the city's multicultural inspirations.
Stroll around, lose yourself in the traboules and alleyways of the Croix-Rousse, and, for a moment, imagine the swirling rhythms of the weaving of Lyon's silk workers, the famous canuts. Take a moment to appreciate the legendary banter of the traditional puppet 'Guignol', created in around 1808 by Laurent Mourguet, and smell the mouth-watering aromas wafting from the kitchens of 'Lyon's Mothers'.
This is Lyon… With its bouchons (the traditional Lyonnais restaurants), brasseries, and Michelin-starred restaurants, Lyon is the capital of French gastronomy, and its many chefs shine in the haute cuisine hall of fame. The Bocuse d'Or - paying tribute to chef Paul Bocuse, its most illustrious ambassador who passed away in January 2018 - acknowledges these chefs' culinary expertise throughout the world.
But this captivating city has many other equally refined and exceptional facets. Over the seasons, artistic biennales and festivals are linked: contemporary dance performances flirt with rock concerts, while the arts are on display at the Confluences Museum. During the summer, the stars twinkle for the Fourvière Nights concerts, and in winter, the Festival of Lights illuminates the night sky, setting Lyon's monuments ablaze with a thousand sparkles. The creative spirit of the Left Bank is more alive than ever on the walls of buildings adorned with monumental frescoes illustrating the past and contemporary history of the city. As the host city for the a number of football matches in the upcoming 2024 Summer Olympics, Lyon regularly sees top-flight games being played in the Parc Olympique Lyonnais, also known as the Groupama Stadium.
Lyon intoxicates the senses. As night falls, a merry bustle invades the streets, glasses of Beaujolais clink, the hour of the sacrosanct aperitif rings out. Laughter is heard, conversations ignite, and conviviality reigns over every table. Lyon combines exaltation with a good life that you will get to appreciate in any number of ways; by walking along the welcoming banks of the Rhône and Saône, or by going for a picnic in the Tête d'Or Park, and so much more.

content.title: On the footsteps of Lyon's street art

introduction.small: Painted murals, graphic collages, colourful staircases… visit the lively and arty slopes of Croix-Rousse through its street art.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: On the footsteps of Lyon's street art

paragraphs.text:
Walls used like canvas: this technique is already tried and proved in Lyon. Well before street art became popular, huge frescoes coloured the streets of the city in the 1980s. Today, wall paintings, arty store fronts and underground works take up the slopes of the Croix-Rousse district. Get ready to climb up to the top of the hill in order to discover this unusual side of the city!

Start your exploration on Rue Prunelle and its colourful staircase. Walking along the Jardin des Plantes, keep your eyes open for various short-term creations like Kesa's vinyl collages or Toki Art's pill-like fictional characters. On Rue Saint-Polycarpe, look up for Caj's Droit dans le mur ("Straight into the wall"), two legs stuck in the air. Head to the top of the blue staircase by Wenc on Passage Mermet and carry on Rue Neyret where David Bowie's different coloured eyes painted by Big Ben make for a great hypnosis session.

Do not pass by the artful ground of this open-air gallery and look for its adorned mosaic. This is called flacking, a technique created in Lyon by artist Ememem, who transformed cracks in the concrete into colourful touches. Once you reach the Croix-Rousse plateau, end your stroll through the city by gazing at a must-see: the Fresque des Canuts. This huge 1,200 sqm window-dressing - the largest wall painting in Europe - was actually one of the very first of its kind in the city, and it changed over time. From silk workers to Vélovs, realistic details tell the story of Lyon in pictures.

Greater Lyon Tourist Office
Place Bellecour
69002 Lyon

+33 (0)4 72 77 69 69

https://en.lyon-france.com/Discover-Lyon/heritage-unesco/Remarkable-sites-and-monuments/canut-wall-painting

content.title: Ninkasi, Lyon's musical microbrewery

introduction.small: The various Ninkasi bars, scattered all over the city, are an essential part of Lyon's nightlife. They are inspired by the American tradition and combine local craft beers, burgers and music.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Ninkasi, Lyon's musical microbrewery

paragraphs.text:
Borrowing its name from the goddess of beer, the Lyon-based micro-brewery Ninkasi created its first beers in 1997, before quickly becoming an institution. Over the past 20 years, some 20 locations have sprung up from Saint-Étienne to Villeurbanne, so that today most towns in the region and areas of the city have their very own "Ninkasi" bar, where locals sit to order one of the homemade beers. Originally located in the Gerland district, the micro-brewery moved to Tarare in 2012, a few kilometres north of Lyon, and it is also open for visits.

Thanks to the space left vacant by the brewing vats, the former Ninkasi HQ is now also the largest establishment in the chain. More than just a bar and restaurant, Ninkasi Gerland is in fact a venue in its own right with two music stages, including the Ninkasi Kao, a 700-seat venue with an eclectic programme. Attend a concert and have a taste - in moderation, of course - of the original creation of the month or the house speciality: black beer. This is a typically Lyonnais malt beverage with caramel and chocolate accents. All of this is enough to perpetuate the region's brewing tradition, which has been famous since the 18th and 19th centuries.

Ninkasi Gerland
267 rue Marcel Mérieux
69007 Lyon

+33 (0)4 72 76 89 00

https://www.ninkasi.fr/lieux/ninkasi-gerland/

Menu: beers from 3 EUR

content.title: Daddy Poule, poultry galore!

introduction.small: Situated in the western part of Lyon, Daddy Poule unveils its chicken-based concept from the plates all the way to the cocktails.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Daddy Poule, poultry galore!

paragraphs.text:
Perched on the rooftop of the Tassin-la-Demi-Lune building on the outskirts of Lyon, Daddy Poule pays tribute to poultry, cooked in many ways by chef Philippe Gauvreau. The inside of the restaurant extends the metaphor by providing clear wooden tables, which are very similar to the roof of a henhouse. Just like the name suggests ("poule" meaning hen in French, and riffing on "Daddy cool"), puns are a favourite here. On the menu for instance, you can order "cock'tails", the piña colada becomes a "Mère Poule" (French for "overprotective mother") and a margarita an "Acapouleco".
When it comes to the food, all things chicken come in various forms: in a wrap, in supreme sauce, as slow-cooked thighs with a lemon-honey juice… Eggs are prepared the "p'tit gone" way (local slang for "kid"), soft-boiled with a tomato purée. When night falls, take a seat on the wooden terrace filled with plants and listen to local bands. Before heading back home, you can also enjoy the custom photo booth using a "hen" filter to keep an original souvenir from your experience.

Daddy Poule
173 avenue Charles-de-Gaulle
69160 Tassin-la-Demi-Lune

+33 (0)4 89 51 33 53

https://www.daddy-poule.com/

Menu: around 23 EUR

content.title: Gabriella, a gastronomic journey in an Italian trattoria

introduction.small: A cross between a Tuscan deli and Puglian trattoria, Gabriella offers authentic Italian cuisine, with a wide range of pizzas.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Gabriella, a gastronomic journey in an Italian trattoria

paragraphs.text:
When you enter the Gabriella restaurant, only a stone's throw from Place Bellecour, your eyes will linger on the profuse decoration. Mismatched tableware and retro furniture give a warm feeling, although one question remains: how did the petrol blue Vespa delivery tricycle end up in there? The vehicle has been turned into a counter, ready to welcome all foodies. In the kitchen, ingredients are selected from the best Italian producers, as you will witness when you read the menu, which points out their origin on a map. Your heart will be torn between the Valentina pizza (tomatoes, a creamy burrata centre, pecorino, coppa and basil) and the Lucilla (tomatoes, Salerno fior di latte, eggplant, zucchini, mushrooms, cherry tomatoes and peppers). Combine business and pleasure and learn some Italian basics from the menu, like the expression "la fame è il miglior intingolo" (hunger makes the best sauce) or, more simply, "un poco più di Parmigiano" (more Parmesan)… and order your pizza like a true Italian!

Gabriella - Le Clan des Mamma
4 rue de Fleurieu
69002 Lyon

+33 (0)4 78 37 00 54

www.leclandesmamma.com/gabriella-lyon/

Menu: around 23 EUR

content.title: The Bocuse Brasseries, seven universes in the City of Lights

introduction.small: Wherever you are in Lyon, you will not be far from a Brasserie Bocuse. An opportunity to try his chefs' exceptional dishes.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Bocuse Brasseries, seven universes in the City of Lights

paragraphs.text:
United in their desire to offer modern and innovative cuisine, the duo Paul Bocuse and Jean Fleury launched the adventure of the Bocuse Brasseries in Lyon. The purchase of their first brasserie, Le Nord, in 1994, was followed by six others, spread out around the city, each with its own identity.

Le Nord (the North) revisits Lyon traditions with dishes such as chicken à la crème. Le Sud (the South) reminds you of the sun with its Mediterranean cuisine (bouillabaisse fish soup and thin pizza with caramelised Mediterranean vegetables), while L'Est (the East) invites you to travel and highlights fish as the star attraction: marinated or grilled, the salmon and cod will delight you. As for the L'Ouest (the West), here they look to islands, from the West Indies to Japan, so you can taste dishes from all over the world. With its sunny terrace, Fond Rose will treat you to frog's legs and Bresse chicken in morels. In an early 20th-century villa that once belonged to Marguerite and Auguste Lumière, the Restaurant Marguerite offers traditional cuisine with a modern twist, with dishes ranging from confit lamb shank to salmon escalope with sorrel.
The Brasserie des Lumières rises above the Olympique Lyonnais' Groupama stadium, with unobstructed views over the field. From "Miéral" Bresse chicken à la crème with morel mushrooms and confit cod loin in virgin olive oil, the menu mixes traditional recipes and iconic dishes from the Bocuse brasseries.

content.title: Mercure Lyon Centre Beaux-Arts, at the heart of the city

introduction.small: At the heart of the Presqu'île peninsula, between the Rhône and Saône rivers, the Mercure Lyon Centre Beaux-Arts Hotel is ideally located to discover the charms of the city of lights.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Mercure Lyon Centre Beaux-Arts, at the heart of the city

paragraphs.text:
Listed as a UNESCO World Heritage site, the Presqu'île peninsula is Lyon's central district. It is very lively and includes shopping streets as well as the Place Bellecour and the Confluences Museum. This is where you will find the Mercure Lyon Centre Beaux-Arts Hotel, in a stunning 19th-century building only a stone's throw from the Place des Jacobins and its charming fountain.

Each of the 76 rooms is furnished in an Art Deco style and has been decorated in cream, chocolate, mustard and pistachio tones. Book one with a balcony, from which you will be able to distinguish the Fourvière Basilica, a monument that you will absolutely have to visit. The hotel does not have a restaurant but is located only a few steps from rue Mercière, known for its plethora of bars, cafés and bistros for you to try. You should also cross the Saône and discover the charms of a traditional bouchon in Old Lyon.

Hôtel Mercure Lyon Centre Beaux-Arts
73-75 rue du Président Édouard Herriot
69002 Lyon

+33 (0)4 78 38 09 50

hotel-mercure-lyon-centre-beauxarts.com/en/

Rooms: from 129 EUR

content.title: Comptoir Chabert, the must in Old Lyon

introduction.small: Legendary places,bouchons in Lyon are a part of local culture. Make the most of your stay in Lyon to discover Comptoir Chabert, without a doubt the best in town.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Comptoir Chabert, the must in Old Lyon

paragraphs.text:
The old town district of Old Lyon, with its cobbled streets, old buildings and famous narrow traboules and passageways, is full of charm. And the many Lyon bouchons you come across add a lot to the atmosphere. Among them, Comptoir Chabert, on the banks of the Saône, is not to be missed. Before you enter, take a look at the slopes of the Croix-Rousse on the other side of the riverbank: it will be a good idea to take a walk after lunch.

Inside, the vaulted ceiling, busy decoration, wooden tables and chairs add to the warm and authentic atmosphere of Comptoir Chabert. There, as in any self-respecting bouchon, you will discover the specialties of Lyon: the andouillette sausage, pike quenelles or the famous cervelle de canut (silk worker's brains - not to worry, it is just a cheese-based dip!). To respect the tradition of the bouchon, accompany your meal with a glass of wine. Go for the Saint-Joseph, a typical wine of the region, produced by an independent winemaker.

Comptoir Chabert
14 quai Romain Rolland
69005 Lyon

+33 (0)4 78 42 99 65

https://www.chezchabert.com/en/

Menu: around 27 EUR

content.title: Saint-Jean-Baptiste de Lyon Primate, the city's cathedral

introduction.small: From the banks of the Saône, you will see the bell tower of the local "Saint-Jean Cathedral", one of the city's oldest churches; and essential part of the Festival of Lights.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Saint-Jean-Baptiste de Lyon Primate, the city's cathedral

paragraphs.text:
At the foot of the Fourvière hill in the heart of Old Lyon, the Saint-Jean-Baptiste de Lyon Primate is better known as “Saint-Jean-Baptiste Cathedral” or simply Lyon Cathedral. It is the church of the Archbishop who is still Primate of the Gauls. On several occasions it has served as the setting for important events in France's history: the marriage of Henri IV and Marie de' Medici in 1600 or the ceremony for the presentation of the cardinal's biretta to Richelieu in 1622. Built on ancient churches whose ruins still exist, the present cathedral dates from the 12th century and has been modified over the ages.

Its gothic naves, Roman choir, and side chapels bear witness to these successive additions, like its nine-metre-high astronomical clock, which dates from the 14th century.

Its facade is an iconic setting for the Festival of Lights, which is held each year in December. During this event, the architectural details of the cathedral, and most notably its central rose window, are illuminated and highly staged by a spectacle of light and sound.

Saint-Jean-Baptiste Primate Cathedral
Place Saint-Jean
69005 Lyon

+33 (0)4 78 81 48 81

https://en.lyon-france.com/discover-lyon/heritage-unesco/Religious-heritage/saint-john-s-cathedral

content.title: Tony Bertrand Nautical Centre, of Olympic stature

introduction.small: In summer, with its Nautical Centre built for its 1968 Olympic bid, which has since been renovated, the city of Lyon is transformed into a seaside and sports resort.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Tony Bertrand Nautical Centre, of Olympic stature

paragraphs.text:
This nautical complex on Quai Claude Bernard in Guillotière occupies the banks of the Rhône like a docked ship. Built by Lyon-born architect Alexandre Audouze-Tabourin for the city's bid for the 1968 Summer Olympics, its pools have been completely renovated and are at the forefront of aquatic modernity. They are now also named after the city's former deputy mayor in charge of sports, Tony Bertrand, who initiated the project. You can swim here in summer and winter, both indoors and outdoors. At 50 x 21m, with water heated to 27°C, the southeastern Olympic pool is open all year round. Swimmers can enjoy a panoramic view of the Hôtel-Dieu, overlooked by the Fourvière basilica, while doing their lengths. At 68 x 24m, the northern pool is only open during the summer months and offers family leisure activities such as bubbling hot tubs, a waterslide, a counter-current stream, and a paddling pool. Last but not least, the water garden hosts aqua aerobics and fitness sessions, beach soccer and beach volleyball.

Centre nautique Tony Bertrand
8 quai Claude Bernard
69007 Lyon

+33 (0)4 78 72 04 50

https://www.lyon.fr/lieu/piscines-ete/centre-nautique-tony-bertrand-ex-piscine-du-rhone

content.title: Sofitel Lyon Bellecour, a safe bet

introduction.small: Just a few minutes from the Fourvière basilica, traboules, and Lyon opera house, Sofitel Lyon Bellecour is a chic, classic local institution.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Sofitel Lyon Bellecour, a safe bet

paragraphs.text:
If you are visiting Lyon for the first time, book yourself in at this 164-room city centre hotel: no matter how long you are staying, it has everything to make your time here a total success. The Rhône flows at its door and the Place Bellecour is within walking distance. The view of Lyon is unique, with its terrace on the eighth floor.

Do not be tempted to order breakfast in bed, but instead head to the panoramic dining room of the restaurant to enjoy the morning light and the copious buffet. At nightfall, come back to gaze at the breathtaking view of the illuminated city from the bar, with a drink in hand, or sit at a table in the Trois Dômes, the hotel's Michelin-starred restaurant by chef Christian Lherm up on the eighth floor. It must be said that the hotel is one of the most luxurious in the city. The rooms are classics and the service is typically Lyonnais - everything comes with a smile.

Sofitel Lyon Bellecour
20 quai Gailleton
69002 Lyon

+33 (0)4 72 41 20 20

https://sofitel.accor.com/hotel/0553/index.en.shtml

Rooms: from 165 EUR

content.title: La Villa Florentine, the heritage of history

introduction.small: When it comes to luxury, this is absolute excellence. Just a stone's throw from the Basilica of Notre-Dame de Fourvière, the Villa Florentine overlooks the city.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: La Villa Florentine, the heritage of history

paragraphs.text:
Gracing Fourvière hill since the 17th century, this former convent symbolises the epitome of excellence and refinement amidst flamboyant Renaissance architecture.

Villa Florentine displays exceptional decor, reflecting its rich past and Italian-influenced splendour. The 29 rooms, suites and apartments are a tribute to the resplendence of the Enlightenment. Each has its own history expressed in its own way by the choice of colours, furniture, and carefully selected objects. Balconies or private terraces offer an enchanting view over the rooftops of Old Lyon.

Every moment is a wonder that you will want to share: dipping into the infinity pool under a blue sky; succumbing to the treasures and flavours of the Michelin-starred Les Terrasses de Lyon fine dining restaurant, headed up by the talented chef David Delsart; or simply enjoying the enchanting calm of this place, while strolling along the garden paths.

Villa Florentine
25 montée Saint-Barthélemy
69005 Lyon

+33 (0)4 72 56 56 56

https://www.villaflorentine.com/en/

Rooms: from 250 EUR

content.title: Museum of Contemporary Art, culture in all its forms

introduction.small: Opened in 1984 in the former 'Palais de la Foire de Lyon' (Fairground Palace), in 1995 the macLYON moved to a new building designed by the Italian architect Renzo Piano.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Museum of Contemporary Art, culture in all its forms

paragraphs.text:
The Museum of Contemporary Art (known as the macLYON) was designed not to exhibit permanent collections but to individually stage each temporary exhibition. This is why the space is so unusual. Here, the walls move, changing place according to the needs and desires of artists. With 3,000 sqm available to them, you can imagine the creative freedom this offers those artists. This is precisely how Cai Guo Qiang managed to form a Swiss mountain here and Mathieu Briand installed a saltwater pool. At each show, it's a new museum that reinvents itself and pushes the limits of creation. Every two years, the museum also hosts Lyon's Biennale of Contemporary Art.

Even if these spectacles are not necessarily your cup of tea, the museum is still worth a visit, if only for its location opposite the Tête d'Or park and its view of the city.

Museum of Contemporary Art (macLYON)
81 Quai Charles de Gaulle
69006 Lyon

+33 (0)4 72 69 17 17

https://www.mac-lyon.com/en

content.title: MiHotel, it's a secret

introduction.small: A new concept of stylish private suites invites you into charming apartments in Lyon in the heart of the Presqu'île peninsula below Place Bellecour.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: MiHotel, it's a secret

paragraphs.text:
Nathalie Grynbaum and Stephanie Marquez-Boucetla have imported the concept of the private suite to Lyon. You choose your suite on their website, pay your reservation and receive your secret code, the key that will open the doors upon arrival at this secret address. Each suite is situated in the heart of the Presqu'île peninsula, in the prestigious area just across from Place Bellecour. Depending on how your mood takes you, you can choose between ”Opale” with its sleek Haussmanian style, large mirror, marble fireplace, coving and parquet floors, “Esmeralda” for arty, urban surroundings designed and styled by Nathalie Rives, or "Hyggelig" for its warm Danish style.

Tastefully decorated in delicate and hushed tones, with contemporary furnishings made by artisans from the region, they combine style and charm. Your stay is independent, but with all the luxury amenities you would expect from a hotel.

Available and ready to meet your every desire, personal concierges will organise wine tours, yoga classes, and quality room service on request.

MiHotel
29 Place Bellecour (offices)
69002 Lyon

+33 (0)4 28 29 65 94

https://www.mihotel.fr/accueil

Rooms: from 149 EUR

content.title: Museum of Fine Arts: homage to Lyon painting

introduction.small: Besides its classic collections, which are among the richest in Europe, this museum pays tribute to the Lyon school of painting.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Museum of Fine Arts: homage to Lyon painting

paragraphs.text:
In 1801, Napoleon decided to open this museum in Lyon in a former Benedictine Abbey, Royale des Dames de Saint-Pierre. The building has since been listed as a historical monument. Its collections have been enriched over the centuries and it is now considered one of the great European museums.

From Ancient Egypt to Modern Art, visiting its five departments is fascinating, but if you are short of time, focus on the two rooms dedicated to Lyonnais painters.

Much more than simple regional painting, the School of Lyon has represented a movement called the Troubadour style of painting since the 1810s. This movement is characterised by its idealised depictions of the Middle Ages, and reappropriation of a number of its popular themes, including floral renderings. Major artists such as Jean-Claude Bonnefond, Pierre Revoil, and Fleury Richard are showcased extensively here. Not to be missed: the 18 paintings that make up the cycle of the Poem of the Soul by Louis Janmot, a series of paintings, drawings and a poem that took the artist half a century to complete.

If the sun is shining, climb the four floors of the museum and enjoy one of the most beautiful views of Lyon from the terrace. Be sure to visit the gardens too. Fine Arts Students are often there drawing the statues, including those of Auguste Rodin, and often make sketches of the visitors too.

Musée des Beaux-Arts de Lyon
20 Place des Terreaux
69001 Lyon

+33 (0)4 72 10 17 40

https://www.mba-lyon.fr/fr

content.title: OKKO Hotels Pont Lafayette, very contemporary

introduction.small: A relaxed four-star for urban discovery weekends on Lyon's cobblestones.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: OKKO Hotels Pont Lafayette, very contemporary

paragraphs.text:
Housed in the former prefecture in the heart of the celebrated 6th district, this renovated 19th-century building offers a new package for a friendly, informal stay.

Forget about the conventions of hospitality, the team at OKKO Hotels Pont Lafayette has decided to offer a resolutely innovative experience. With an all-inclusive package, the hotel offers four-star service that will satisfy even the most demanding of guests: modern decor, easy access to new technologies, quality equipment, video on demand, gym, and snacks to help yourself to.

The rooms, created by French designer Patrick Norquet, are designed to offer no-frills comfort, thanks to a thoughtful, creative approach combining aesthetics and functionality in the service of quality. Through the large period window or from the balcony, you can watch the changing colours as the day progresses over the Rhône, spanned by the Lafayette Bridge, and the Croix-Rousse hill in front of you.

OKKO Hotels Pont Lafayette
14 bis Quai du Général Sarrail
69006 Lyon

+33 (0)4 28 00 02 50

https://www.okkohotels.com/en/page/lyon/.3097.html

Rooms: from 94 EUR

content.title: Old Lyon, the Renaissance district

introduction.small: The oldest district of Lyon displays a gentle, romantic Florentine influence.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Old Lyon, the Renaissance district

paragraphs.text:
At the foot of Fourvière hillside, Old Lyon (in French, "le Vieux Lyon") is appropriately named, since this district dates from the Middle Ages. It was at this time that the first traboules were built to facilitate the passage of goods from the banks of the Rhône towards houses built on pilings.

Later, during the Renaissance, and thanks to Marie de Medici, Florentines settled here and built houses whose interiors are authentic works of the Italian Quattrocento. Some still exist but are private, though you can still visit certain courtyards. It is also possible to walk through the traboules, alleyways that run between and through the houses. Are they underground? No, they are secret passages of Gothic architecture that can go from one street to another, often crossing building courtyards.

Old Lyon is completely pedestrianised, so you can stroll at leisure through the streets, which have not confined themselves completely to the past, providing multiple temptations with their bakeries, old bookstores, and lively cafés.

Vieux Lyon
69005 Lyon

https://en.lyon-france.com/discover-lyon/heritage-unesco/Renaissance/the-old-lyon-district

content.title: Slo living hostel, place of sharing

introduction.small: For travellers from all over in search of conviviality and sharing, this hostel is yours.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Slo living hostel, place of sharing

paragraphs.text:
Forget crowded and noisy dormitories, here is an example of the new generation of hostels that certain hotels might envy. The spirit of sharing is always at the heart of this place, with its large table d'hôte and bar, where everyone can talk about their travels, or their encounters and projects. Accents of the world resonate happily on all sides, and the atmosphere soon becomes warm around Lyonnais specialties washed down with a glass or two of fruit juice or local wine. Two evenings a week are dedicated to tasting the local cuisine.

The setting is suitable for meetings, with bright and clear spaces while the decor displays a stylish Scandinavian spirit accentuated with small touches of bright colours.

Ideally located in one of the liveliest areas of the city, five minutes away from the banks of the Rhône, the hostel offers nine rooms for one to eight people to all those who seek a different traveller's experience, whether they are students, single travellers, families, or businesspeople.

Slo living hostel
5 rue Bonnefoi
69003 Lyon

content.title: Regional wines from the vineyards of Beaujolais

introduction.small: Set off on the hilly roads of the Beaujolais region and discover its passion for wine. A journey in the land of wine, from Saint-Amour to Chiroubles.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Regional wines from the vineyards of Beaujolais

paragraphs.text:
Rent a car in search of the wine that is said by experts to be the most sensual of all. The Beaujolais vineyards are some of the most picturesque in the world, with narrow roads winding through sloping vineyards. Follow the valley from Lyon to Mâcon through 55 km of vineyard-filled countryside. The Gamay grape reigns supreme here: it is the only variety permitted for making Beaujolais, and is what gives these red wines their range of body and depth. Each village has given its name to a famous growth: Saint-Amour, Chiroubles, Juliénas, Brouilly, Morgon…

Winemakers work the land and the vine to develop wines sometimes referred to as 'masculine', with a rich, aromatic, and complex palette that they share with their Burgundian neighbours. Beaujolais wine is convivial and made for sharing. The harvesting season is a direct witness to this: it is a time of gathering when everyone picks the bunches of grapes by hand, since this is one of the remaining regions to resist mechanical harvesting.

Every third Thursday of November, connoisseurs celebrate the arrival of the new Beaujolais in bistros throughout the country. It is practically a national celebration, and can be witnessed all over France!

Destination Beaujolais (Tourist Information office)
96 rue de la sous-préfecture
69400 Villefranche-sur-Saône

+33 (0)4 74 07 27 40

https://www.destination-beaujolais.com/en/la-route-des-vins.html

content.title: Tête d'Or park, Lyon's wide prairie

introduction.small: Considered the beating heart of Lyon, the Tête d'Or park is one of the largest parks in Europe, and a point of pride for the land of gastronomy.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Tête d'Or park, Lyon's wide prairie

paragraphs.text:
Back when New York was inaugurating Central Park, the lawns in Lyon's Tête d'Or park has already been open since 1857. For fans of treasure, legend has it that a golden head of Christ is buried here, which is how it got its name.

Swiss landscapers and brothers Denis and Eugène Bühler based its geography on English gardens, providing it with a botanical garden, zoo and lake, as well as many buildings that include large greenhouses, a velodrome, and the Chalet des Gardes. Later, a memorial to the dead was erected on the Island of Swans. With more than 30,000 roses from 350 different varieties, rose lovers should not miss the rose garden at any price.

The Tête d'Or park is locals' favourite place to stroll and enjoy lunch on the grass, for generations young and old. It is up to you to choose what you like best about the park: a romantic boat trip on the lake, yoga classes in the gardens, strolling among the flower beds, a gourmet picnic in the shade of the Lebanese cedars, bike races, and much more to discover.

The seasons leave their mark, the city disappears, and nature is queen.

Parc de la Tête d'Or
69006 Lyon

https://www.loisirs-parcdelatetedor.com

content.title: Place Bellecour carries its name well

introduction.small: In Lyon, all roads converge here. With its central position, the Place Bellecour is an essential stop for any walk on the Presqu'île peninsula.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Place Bellecour carries its name well

paragraphs.text:
You cannot talk about Lyon without mentioning Bellecour. It is impossible to come to Lyon without crossing this six-hectare square, one of the largest in France, at one time or another.

In the heart of the Presqu'île peninsula between the Rhône and the Saône, this strategic crossroads of Lyonnais life is at the junction of three major arteries: the Rue de la République leading to Lyon's National Opera House, the shop-lined Rue Herriot heading for the Place des Terreaux, and Rue Victor Hugo running to the Perrache and Confluence neighbourhoods. In its centre, you will find a grandiose equestrian statue of Louis XIV riding Roman-style without stirrups. If locals are planning to meet up in the city centre, under the royal horse's tail is.a popular rendez-vous spot.

For rollerblade fans, it is at the statue's feet that every Friday night, skating enthusiasts gather for their nocturnal tours of the city.

Place Bellecour
69002 Lyon

https://en.lyon-france.com/discover-lyon/heritage-unesco/Remarkable-sites-and-monuments/Place-Bellecour

content.title: Lugdunum, back to the origins

introduction.small: Witness to the Gallo-Roman city of Lugdunum, the museum retraces the ancient history of Lyon through archaeological artefacts and two wonderfully preserved Roman theatres.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Lugdunum, back to the origins

paragraphs.text:
Lyon was the capital of Gaul and it is on the ruins of the ancient city of Lugdunum, the ancient name of Lyon, that this museum was built. The architect, Bernard Zehrfuss, designed a reinforced concrete structure that blends in with the old stones and a scenography that goes back in time from prehistory to the 7th century AD. The museum's impressive archaeological collection includes the famous Claudian Table, or Lyon Tablet (a bronze plaque inscribed with the speech Emperor Claudius made before the Roman Senate in the year 48 AD). Along an unusual underground route, discover the life of the inhabitants of Lugdunum through artefacts relating the daily life of the time, such as ceramics, sculptures, mosaics, jewels and much more.

Outside, the large Roman theatre and Odeon reflect the scope of the Gallo-Roman city. In summer the gardens are animated by the Fourviere Nights, with concerts and sound-and-light shows.

Lugdunum Museum & Roman Theatres
17 Rue Cleberg
69005 Lyon

+33 (0)4 72 38 49 30

https://lugdunum.grandlyon.com/en/

content.title: Lyon Opera, for a night at the opera

introduction.small: With its “popping” hip hop dancers in its square, and its contemporary glass dome, Lyon Opera is the height of modernity.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Lyon Opera, for a night at the opera

paragraphs.text:
Its unusual appearance surprises as much as it delights. The Lyon Opera has one foot in the classical and the other in the contemporary, both in its architecture and programming.

Renovated by Jean Nouvel, all that remains of the old building are the four walls and the public foyer. A symbol of contemporary architecture, a glass roof crowns the opera house and shelters dance studios, as well as a bar with a panoramic view of Lyon. Its seasons still subtly combine various musical and ballet repertories.

Do not miss the opportunity to attend a show, especially since many companies will give their first performances here before going on international tour. Some have even made their debut in the square in front of the opera house, a meeting point for breakdance fans since the 1990s. These include the urban dance collective Pockemon Crew, the most successful hip hop company in the world who have set an international standard.

Opéra de Lyon
1 Place de la Comédie
69001 Lyon
+33 (0)4 69 85 54 54

https://www.opera-lyon.com/en

content.title: Le Télécabine takes you to higher grounds

introduction.small: In Villeurbanne, three kilometres from Lyon city centre, this place is so special that once you find it, you will never want to leave.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Le Télécabine takes you to higher grounds

paragraphs.text:
Passionate about design, architect Philippe Domas and art director Anthony Comte have brought a 19th-century textile factory back to life as a hotel that challenges hotel industry convention.

Though the industrial design - metal framing, brick, and concrete - proffers a nod to its former life, a large window, opening onto a huge terrace, floods the place with a light and transforms it into a contemporary space. Not to mention its decoration, which is expressed with boldness, elegance and originality.

The establishment is organised around four areas: a large, main 250-sqm loft, of which 80 sqm are dedicated to a high-tech kitchen, and three small 35-sqm lofts that are equipped with every comfort, complemented by office space and a mezzanine. The concierge will take care of your every wish, freeing you of all concerns.

Le Télécabine (which means "cable car" in French) takes its name from the presence of an 'egg' hanging proudly on the terrace, the remains of the famous 'Devil's Gondola' of the Deux Alps ski resort, bought at a charity auction.

Le Télécabine
48 rue des Charmettes
69100 Villeurbanne

+33 (0)7 51 64 71 91 / +33 (0)6 09 87 71 04

https://www.facebook.com/Le-t%C3%A9l%C3%A9cabine-1469722323277921/

Loft room: 120, 160 or 220 EUR per night depending on the time of year, and from 500 EUR per week

content.title: Lumière Brothers Institute, birthplace of cinema

introduction.small: The cinematheque that is adored by moviegoers worldwide is a must-see.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Lumière Brothers Institute, birthplace of cinema

paragraphs.text:
Founded in 1982 and long chaired by the late Bertrand Tavernier, the famous Lyonnais filmmaker who passed away in 2021, the Lumière Institute is naturally located inside Louis and Auguste Lumière's family villa, at 25 rue du Premier Film, where the two brothers designed their cinematograph. The aim of the Institute, now led by Thierry Frémaux - who is also the director of Cannes Film Festival - is to share and preserve the world's cinematic works.

Since 2005, this unique heritage has been part of UNESCO's Memory of the World Register. The Lumière Museum established at the Institute traces the many inventions of the visionary brothers, and presents a collection of materials, including the famous 'Prototype No. 1': the first projection device in the world. It was “Prototype No. 2', also on display, that Louis and Auguste used to screen their first ten films to a paying audience of 33 people at the Grand Café de Paris in December 1895. Cinema was born! A few metres from there at 15 Rue du Premier Film is the Premier-Film Hangar, where the remains of the Lumière factory - which served as the set for the brothers' very first film - are preserved and displayed.

Be sure to visit the heart of the Institute building as well, where photos and original film posters are exhibited in the Winter Garden.

Institut Lumière
25 Rue du Premier Film
69008 Lyon

+ 33 (0)4 78 78 18 95

http://www.institut-lumiere.org/

content.title: Les Halles de Lyon - Paul Bocuse, the art of eating well

introduction.small: Considered 'the belly of Lyon', the covered market symbolises 'the two secrets of success: quality and creativity' according to Paul Bocuse, after whom they are now named.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Les Halles de Lyon - Paul Bocuse, the art of eating well

paragraphs.text:
Going back in history to the 19th century, the market was originally located on the Place des Cordeliers for more than 100 years, but the demands of a modern society led the mayor, Louis Pradel, to update and move it to a district that was undergoing renovation, La Part Dieu. Inaugurated in 1971, they were renovated in 2006 and now open up to the city with a huge glass wall looking out to the Cours Lafayette.

Les Halles hosts more than 50 oyster shuckers, cheese makers, bakers, pastry chefs, market gardeners, and sausage makers, as well as butchers, fishmongers, caterers, wine merchants, and restaurateurs, all worthy representatives of Lyon's gastronomic expertise.

Although chef Bocuse passed away aged 91 in January 2018, some of his suppliers and their wares are still present. There are still the famous cheeses of Mere Richard and Maréchal there, for example, along with the fishmonger Pupier, cold cuts from Colette Sibilia and Gast, Richard Sève's famous chocolates and Bahadourian dried fruits.

Les Halles de Lyon Paul Bocuse
102 cours Lafayette
69003 Lyon

+33 (0)4 78 62 39 33

https://www.halles-de-lyon-paulbocuse.com

content.title: Le Potager des Halles, good local cuisine

introduction.small: This original, creative cuisine puts a new spin on traditional regional dishes with seasonal produce.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Le Potager des Halles, good local cuisine

paragraphs.text:
When you get to Le Potager des Halles, you can rest assured you will be in good company, as its glass facade offers a breathtaking view of the Fresco of the People of Lyon (Fresque des Lyonnais). This mural honours outstanding personalities who have marked the city's history, like Antoine de Saint Exupéry, brothers Auguste and Louis Lumière, Paul Bocuse, Bertrand Tavernier, and many more...

Inside, you will feel right at home. The chef champions food that showcases classic cooking, using ingredients either from local markets, or local suppliers with whom he has a very close relationship. This freshness is palpable as soon as you taste the salmon gravlax and wasabi whipped cream, poached rhubarb and fried red onions, or duck breast with blackcurrant sauce, garlicky beetroot emulsion and pan-fried shiitake mushrooms. It goes without saying that the menu is constantly changing to reflect what is available and in season, but you can be sure that you will always find something on there to whet your appetite, be it meat or vegetables. The restaurant also serves brunch on Saturdays and Sundays, which is a firm favourite with local foodies.

Le Potager des Halles
3 rue de la Martinière
69001 Lyon

+33 (0)4 72 00 24 84

www.lepotagerdeshalles.com

Menu: around 28.50 EUR (lunch set menu is 19.90 EUR and brunch set menu is 29 EUR)

content.title: Lyon Botanical Garden, a floral paradise

introduction.small: A favourite spot for lovers of botany, this garden is an invitation to travel the world and discover its floral splendour.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Lyon Botanical Garden, a floral paradise

paragraphs.text:
Part of the Tête d'Or park, this garden extends over eight hectares. The extraordinary richness of its collections makes it one of the largest botanical gardens in Europe. It lists 15,000 plant species, while its 6,500 sqm of greenhouses preserve 6,000 rare plant varieties from around the world.

During your walk, you can admire all kinds of incredible species, from the most common to the most exotic. You will be equally as enamoured with the French gardens as with the greenhouses, with their carnivorous and aquatic plants. Pride of place is reserved for the international rose garden, which has over 30,000 roses from 350 different varieties.

Later, cool off in the shade of the woods, explore the small winter and bamboo gardens, and discover some original tree varieties, such as the Virginia tulip tree, and the Ginkgo biloba, also known as the “tree of 40 crowns”...

To share the beauty and help you discover the splendour of this garden, free guided tours are offered, as well as instructional workshops, all year long.

Jardin Botanique de Lyon
Parc de la Tête d'Or
69006 Lyon

+33 (0)4 72 43 04 57

www.jardin-botanique-lyon.com/jbot/

content.title: Court-Circuit, a restaurant showcasing local ingredients

introduction.small: An unusual place, designed for tasting simple pleasures and experiencing the atmosphere of the lively Guillotière district.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Court-Circuit, a restaurant showcasing local ingredients

paragraphs.text:
It is all in the name. The concept of the Court-Circuit (short circuit) supports local, small, organic production with an unpretentious menu but one whose quality and freshness are impeccable.

It is a citizen's movement, and the initiative has had no difficulty finding followers: this bar and restaurant is always full. The dishes on the menu follow the seasons and highlight forgotten products such as Jerusalem artichokes and parsnips... Only the cheese is not homemade but exclusively sourced from small local producers.

The dishes are generous, and vegetarians as well as lovers of good meat will be well served here - and a vegan option has even made its way onto the menu now. A rendez-vous hot spot, the Court-Circuit draws a dynamic crowd that loves to gather around a local tipple (walnut wine, beers from regional microbreweries, soda made in Monts d'Or, homemade iced tea) and plates of nibbles while commenting on an exhibition, a film, or a concert.

Court-Circuit
13 rue Jangot
69007 Lyon

+33 (0)9 54 36 61 29

https://www.le-court-circuit.fr

Menu: around 20 EUR

content.title: Les Loges, gastronomically yours

introduction.small: Gastronomy combining luxury, calm, and sensual delight.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Les Loges, gastronomically yours

paragraphs.text:
It was logical that the Cour des Loges palace should have a restaurant, and as soon as it did, it was crowned with a Michelin star. The cuisine of young chef Anthony Bonnet and his teams is at the exalted heights of the establishment. Imagine a marble-paved courtyard lined with three floors of balconies and galleries, and, as a ceiling, a contemporary glass canopy.

In this idyllic setting, the menu luxuriates around the most noble local ingredients, seasoned to perfection and paired with the most delectable accompaniments there are: duck foie gras served in an orange and confit escalope in duck broth, brown trout, sorrel cream, vegetable minestrone, lamb from the Haute-Loire mountains with stuffed baby vegetables straight out of the Abbé Rosier farm - a local institution for the past 200 years -, or baked apple, meringue, celery and farm cider…
At Les Loges, each dish becomes a unforgettable sensory experience!

Les Loges
Cour des Loges Lyon, A Radisson Collection Hotel

content.title: Cruise on the Rhône and Saône rivers for unbeatable views

introduction.small: Leave dry land and navigate Lyon's unmissable waterways. What better than a river trip to see the city from another angle?

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Cruise on the Rhône and Saône rivers for unbeatable views

paragraphs.text:
Lyon is best explored on foot, by bike…or by boat. Take the time for a romantic dinner cruise at twilight, or a few hours in the afternoon and you will get a completely different view of Old Lyon, the banks of the Saône and the Rhône, the Confluence neighbourhood, and the hill of Croix-Rousse. The view becomes panoramic. The subtle palette of the ochre facades dazzles you and the many details of Renaissance architecture are best revealed from the water. As the cruise progresses, listen to the details of the eventful history of the city of Lyon as you travel north up the river from an urban setting to a more authentic landscape.

The uniqueness of this city that harmoniously oscillates between past and present becomes obvious. It is a highly original way of understanding the ancient Gallic capital and its green geography, between urban quays, its untamed banks, and unspoilt and sparsely populated Barbe Island.

Greater Lyon Tourist Office
Place Bellecour
69002 Lyon

+33 (0)4 72 77 69 69

https://en.lyon-france.com/discover-lyon/week-end-activity-ideas/lyon-by-the-water

content.title: La Mère Brazier, Lyon's star

introduction.small: A vibrant, contemporary tribute to the most famous of Lyon mothers, the icons of local gastronomy.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: La Mère Brazier, Lyon's star

paragraphs.text:
'The Blazing Brazier' is what the poet Jacques Prévert called her. It is impossible not to mention Eugenie Brazier when you talk about Lyon gastronomy. She was 20 when she discovered cooking and 25 when she opened her own 'bouchon' (the traditional Lyonnais restaurant). She never left her stove until the age of 72 and was the first woman to twice receive three Michelin stars. She embodies the excellence of Lyonnais gastronomy, and it was in her restaurant that a young boy named Paul Bocuse apprenticed.

In 2008, Mathieu Viannay, Meilleur Ouvrier de France in 2004, succumbed to the charm of this institution and bought it. He brought a breath of modernity to the place, while respecting its history and keeping its 1930s décor, tiled flooring, and bay windows.

The chef reinterprets the legendary dishes of Eugenie Brazier with fidelity and sensitivity, like the Bresse chicken, the blue lobster casserole, milk-fed veal fillet studded with anchovies or crispy pain de brochet. The Brazier flame has been stoked again and has already earned multiple Michelin stars.

La Mère Brazier
12 rue Royale
69001 Lyon

+33 (0)4 78 23 17 20

https://lamerebrazier.fr/

Menu: around 160 EUR (lunch set menu 75 EUR)

content.title: Carlton Lyon - MGallery, the little Lyonnais palace

introduction.small: This lavish showcase of timeless elegance, nestled between the Rhône and the Saône, combines late 19th-century architecture and contemporary style.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Carlton Lyon - MGallery, the little Lyonnais palace

paragraphs.text:
Located in the prestigious area of the Presqu'île peninsula, close to the opera house and the Theatre des Célestins, this legendary hotel, built in 1894 and under the aegis of Carlton since 1925, stands proudly in its completely renovated Haussmannian silhouette. Nicknamed the 'little Lyonnais palace' since the 19th century, it has managed to protect its incomparable splendour throughout its 127-year history. Its wrought-iron balconies, resplendent dome, and elegant rotundas are a veritable celebration of French excellence.

Its new look masterfully combines the legacy of its flamboyant past and the modernity of its more contemporary furniture. Its iconic colour, “Carlton Red”, is always in the spotlight, flirting with drapes, plush carpets, and tapestries, and is found in subtle combinations throughout. The intimacy of the rooms, each named after an actor, reveal the delicacy of the decor in luxurious comfort.

Added to the pleasure of gazing are the pleasures of the senses when you discover the room service menu developed hand-in-hand with Le Centre by Georges just next door, run by top chef Georges Blanc.

The hotel bar provides a wealth of different options, to be savoured in moderation of course, including the signature cocktail, Rouge Carlton, in a cosy lounge atmosphere under the glow of pearl chandeliers.

Carlton Hotel Lyon – Mgallery Hotel Collection
4 rue Jussieu
69002 Lyon

+33 (0)4 78 42 56 51

https://www.accorhotels.com/gb/hotel-2950-hotel-carlton-lyon-mgallery-by-sofitel/index.shtml

Rooms: from 144 EUR

content.title: Le Canut et les Gones, not to be missed

introduction.small: Pride of the Croix-Rousse, this typical bistro is renowned for its stunning Franco-Japanese inventiveness.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Le Canut et les Gones, not to be missed

paragraphs.text:
Contrary to what the decor might suggest, you are neither at a watchmaker's, nor in a junk shop, but in Franck Blanc's bistro. Franck set up his stove here in Croix-Rousse more than 20 years ago and has been delighting the palates of the Lyonnais with his typical regional 'terroir' dishes ever since.

Since 2010 he has been working four-handed with his accomplice, the Japanese chef Junzo Matuno. More than his spices, it is the way he cooks and prepares food that allow the Japanese master to give new impetus to good bourgeois cooking: he wakes it up and liberates it.

Imagine the tenderness of a Blonde d'Aquitaine calf's head simmered in stock, flash-roasted and served thinly sliced with an anchovy sauce ravigote, or the delicacy of smoked duck breast with a pea and lovage velouté, pickled mushrooms and Parmesan crumble. The local wines are up to the level of the food and harmoniously accompany each dish.

Le Canut et les Gones
29 rue de Belfort
69004 Lyon

+33 (0)4 78 29 17 23

https://www.lecanutetlesgones.com

Menu: 24 EUR (lunch) and 35 EUR (dinner)

content.title: La place des Terreaux, where the young come together

introduction.small: This square, completely reinvented by artist Daniel Buren, is the hangout for the local youth, who gather in its various bars and restaurants.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: La place des Terreaux, where the young come together

paragraphs.text:
The Terreaux are named after the embankments on which they were built. The place was fortified in the Middle Ages and turned into a market in the Renaissance. When it was paved in the 18th century, it gradually became the administrative and economic centre of the city, as the City Hall and Museum of Fine Arts still testify.

In 1892, a fountain designed as an allegory of the Garonne River by Auguste Bartholdi, the “father” of the Statue of Liberty, was installed in the centre of the square, having originally been carved for the city of Bordeaux. During the successive renovations of the square in 1994 and 2019, the Place des Terreaux has been completely redesigned by artist Daniel Buren. It is now adorned with 44 cubes created by Buren and 15 fountains. It also lights up at nightfall as if its floor were home to another galaxy.

In summer, thanks to the terraces that border it, Les Terreaux is one of the most popular meeting points for young people in Lyon to meet for a drink at happy hour.

Place des Terreaux
69000 Lyon

https://www.lyon-france.com/je-decouvre-lyon/sites-et-monuments/Sites-et-monuments-remarquables/La-Place-des-Terreaux

content.title: Croix-Rousse, the silk district

introduction.small: Marked by its tumultuous history, from worker's revolts at the time of the canuts and Second World War resistance, La Croix-Rousse is now an alternative innovation laboratory.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Croix-Rousse, the silk district

paragraphs.text:
You go up the hill by bus, and come down by foot. At Croix-Rousse, you will find slopes and a plateau. With its silk industry, Croix-Rousse was the first workers' town in France, and that fact still permeates everything there today. Locals have also nicknamed it "the hill that works" - in opposition to its neighbour, "the hill that prays", topped by the Notre-Dame de Fourvière basilica. Its streets still rustle with the silk-workers' revolts, when workers used the traboules with the courage of the Resistance during the Second World War.

Though Lyon is often referred to as a bourgeois city, Croix-Rousse is its rebellious soul and, today, a laboratory of alternative innovation. Start-ups and incubators have set up in its small buildings, with old workshops now transformed into lofts.

The bars and cafes serve health food, and its galleries exhibit the young talents of comic book makers and illustrators.

Greater Lyon Tourist Office
Place Bellecour
69002 Lyon

+33 (0)4 72 77 69 69

https://en.lyon-france.com/Lyon-Metropole-and-the-region/The-districts-of-Lyon/croix-rousse

content.title: Gourmix, local sandwiches

introduction.small: Come and sample an (almost) infinite range of homemade sandwich snacks!

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Gourmix, local sandwiches

paragraphs.text:
The name of this eatery, ‘Gourmix' is a nod to the Celtic origins of the city. Were the Gauls greedy? Here you are tempted to become so. If you get peckish after a trip to the Museum of Fine Arts (Gourmix Terreaux) or on a shopping spree on the Erevan Garden side of the Presqu'île peninsula (Gourmix Confluence), you will be spoiled for choice. Homemade foie gras, rosette de Lyon, ham, mature cheeses and much more are all on offer!

Twenty local ingredients are available in 106 original creations, with sun-dried tomato, rocket, crunchy vegetables, honey and caramelised onions all available to be added to buns straight out of the on-site oven. You can combine different flavour combinations of your choice, just like the French version of tapas, which you put together by checking off the ingredients from the long list available. Depending on your appetite, three to four of these little snacks should be enough. For dessert, try the homemade yoghurt with rhubarb. In the evenings, you can enjoy 'mini'wiches' alongside a glass of regional wine.

Gourmix Terreaux

Gourmix Confluence
Confluence Shopping Centre (Level 2)

content.title: La Fourmilière, good simple food

introduction.small: Good, simple organic, local, and even plant-based food, with good beer; what could be better?

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: La Fourmilière, good simple food

paragraphs.text:
Wondering who the Lyonnais are? In this restaurant located in the heart of Guillotière, a trendy, cosmopolitan area, which has been continuing to gain in popularity since the early 2010s, you will be able to meet them and engage in discussions about everything and nothing over a glass of Beaujolais and a nice juicy steak. The chef's motto here is 'home cooking, hand-crafted, with character'.

To achieve that, he carefully selects local produce and often includes organic products on the menu, not to mention beautiful vegetable plates for fans of good vegetarian cuisine. Lunch or dinner? Unhesitatingly opt for the evening to quietly enjoy a local beer at the bar, such as La Soyeuse or La Grivoise, at the bar while getting to know people over a game of draughts or cards. The evening will run smoothly along to the rhythm of world music concerts or the amateur at the wooden piano of the bar…

La Fourmilière
15 rue Salomon Reinach
69007 Lyon

+33 (0)4 72 73 24 60

https://www.facebook.com/lafourmilierecafe/

Menu: around 17 EUR

content.title: Le Bouchon des Filles, where women call the shots

introduction.small: There are not just Lyon mothers in the kitchen: here we have daughters too.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Le Bouchon des Filles, where women call the shots

paragraphs.text:
At the foot of the Croix-Rousse, Isabelle and Laura have reconnected with the tradition of the Lyonnais mothers (those longstanding figures of local gastronomy, including Mère Guy, Mère Bizolon and Mère Brazier) in a bouchon established in a 18th-century house. Though the setting is still rustic, and pink on every chequered tablecloth, the food puts a lighter, more contemporary twist on classic bouchon fare.

When it comes to the starters, for example, bowls of appetisers and terrines are passed from table to table as was always traditional in these workers' bistros, while on the menu, it is hard to choose between the homemade red mullet quenelles with shellfish and crayfish sauce, pistachio sausage and potatoes, or pork steak pot-au-feu.

For dessert, you will be hard-pressed to withstand the temptation of the lime and cashew cream cheesecake or the dark chocolate ganache with candied mandarins, a Lyon pastry that no one can resist.

Le Bouchon des Filles
20 rue Sergent-Blandan
(Near Place Sathonay)
69001 Lyon

+33 (0)4 78 30 40 44

Menu: set menu for 28 EUR

content.title: Brasserie des Confluences, after the exhibition

introduction.small: When the best of culture meets culinary genius.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Brasserie des Confluences, after the exhibition

paragraphs.text:
You do not just go to the museum for its art and culture anymore, now you also go there for its gastronomy. The Confluences Museum combines different styles and is home to the Brasserie des Confluences. At its head are Michelin-starred chef Guy Lassausaie and Jean-Paul Pignol, Meilleur Ouvrier de France pastry and confectionery chef.

Their expertise comes through in every bourgeois-inspired dish, such as the snail pistou with baby purple artichoke, steamed plaice fillet and quenelle, razor clams stuffed with pine nuts and ginger, or the red berry pavlova. The people of Lyon have spoken, and the brasserie has become a gourmet institution, where you will see plenty of families having lunch on Sundays.

It is worth making a reservation, especially if you want to enjoy the view of the Rhône. At teatime, you can also enjoy a pastry at the Comptoir Gourmand located on the terrace.

Brasserie des Confluences
Musée des Confluences
Ground Floor
86 quai Perrache
69002 Lyon

+33 (0)4 72 41 12 34

https://brasseriedesconfluences.fr

Menu: around 41 EUR (midday set menu 29 EUR)

content.title: La Cour des Loges, Italian refinement

introduction.small: The Italian Renaissance welcomes you to the historic quarter of Old Lyon, where the Cour des Loges is still working on Florentine time.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: La Cour des Loges, Italian refinement

paragraphs.text:
A marvel of Old Lyon, the Cour des Loges invites you to discover Florentine opulence and wealth in a setting where time seems to stand still. Close your eyes and let yourself be carried away by the magic of this Renaissance jewel, a vibrant tribute to the glories of Florence at its cultural zenith. You need only step through its archways to discover its incredible scenery.

Each step takes you to a new surprise: the maze of galleries that wind over three floors, the quiet lounges and the glowing patina walls, hanging gardens, green alcoves above the roofs, and the marble-paved Florentine courtyard. History has left its mark in the secret, comfortable, dimly lit rooms: coffered ceilings, centuries-old woodwork, and heavy curtains flawlessly blend with contemporary furniture by Le Corbusier or Mackintosh.

To complete this exceptional escape, the Clefs d'Or, concierges renowned for their high-end service, are on hand to fulfil your every wish.

Cour des Loges Lyon, A Radisson Collection Hotel
6 rue du Bœuf
69005 Lyon

+33 (0)4 72 77 44 44

https://www.courdesloges.com/en

Rooms: from 236 EUR

content.title: Le Collège Hotel, a real break

introduction.small: With its decor from the 1990s and 2000s conjuring up old memories, this hotel with a sense of humour takes us back to school days.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Le Collège Hotel, a real break

paragraphs.text:
This hotel is a real surprise with its residential atmosphere. At the reception, a gigantic pot of pencils sets the scene, with the blackboards no longer covered with multiplication tables but with the cocktail of the day. The classrooms are transformed into lounges, with walls lined with books and shiny distressed leather sofas. The breakfast buffet awaits you in the dining hall - and fortunately the menu is much more attractive than memories of your school canteens might suggest! There's no bell to announce the gourmet break time at the cafeteria bar, the Baràgones, but you are invited to savour its regional 'Goneries', a collection of twists on classic Lyonnais gourmet canapés to your heart's delight.

The atmosphere, is minimalist, with some of the pristine white rooms offering a splendid view of Fourvière hill and its basilica.

Extra points for the huge retro fridges on all floors, filled with free drinks!

Collège Hôtel
5 place Saint-Paul
69005 Lyon

+33 (0)4 72 10 05 05

https://www.college-hotel.com/en/

Rooms: from 99 EUR

content.title: Confluences Museum, where modernity finds a home

introduction.small: Dedicated to anthropology and the history of civilisations, this museum is also an inspiration to contemporary creation.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Confluences Museum, where modernity finds a home

paragraphs.text:
Deconstructivist architecture designed by Austrian firm Coop Himmelb(l)au defines this building at the confluence (hence its name) of the Saône and the Rhône, on the site of a former gasworks. Opened in 2014, the museum was built in this particular spot to help people forget the mistakes made by 1970s city planners (including the infamous Fourvière tunnel). Its futuristic silhouette, not dissimilar to an immense spaceship, makes a spectacular sight if you are coming from the south of France by the A7 motorway.

Its collections are as impressive as the building itself. Not only does it combine works collected by Lyonnais industrialist Emile Guimet over his lifetime (1836-1918) with collections from a natural history museum founded during the French Revolution and a former colonial museum, but it is also home to a vast array of objects collected during the 19th century by Catholic missionaries. Overall, the Confluence Museum has over two million pieces on display, dating from Prehistory to the modern world. Its daring installations sometimes lend themselves to debate, but no one disputes its status as a cabinet of curiosities. It is also a stakeholder in the Lyon Biennale, and hosts its temporary exhibitions.

Musée des Confluences
86 quai Perrache
69002 Lyon

+33 (0)4 28 38 12 12

www.museedesconfluences.fr/fr/visit-museum

content.title: Creators' Village, tomorrow's greats

introduction.small: A nursery for young talents in fashion, design, and decoration has been established in the heart of the Passage Thiaffait, an old traboule beneath the slopes of Croix-Rousse.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Creators' Village, tomorrow's greats

paragraphs.text:
The Creators' Village was designed to support young Lyonnais stylists and new designers. Its illustrious sponsors include Serge Bensimon, Jérôme Lhuillier, and Chantal Thomass, among others. Every year, the Talents de Mode contest rewards one of these future greats.

The Village is located in Passage Thiaffait, an old traboule (passageway) at the bottom of the slopes of Croix-Rousse that has been totally renovated and transformed into shops and boutiques. A sort of business incubator, the space welcomes and accompanies these young creators for the time it takes them to get started. The brands change every two to three years, which allows them to discover new local brands made in Lyon. In total, around fifty designers exhibit at the Village. The only permanent shop, at the entrance of the passage on the Rue Leynaud side, is VDC/B, a concept store that presents the collections of the designers of the moment. It sells unique pieces, all of which were manufactured in the Auvergne-Rhône-Alpes region: from clothes and accessories to jewellery, ornaments, decorations and more… capsule collections are renewed monthly.

Village des Créateurs
Passage Thiaffait
19 rue René Leynaud
69001 Lyon

+ 33 (0)4 78 27 37 21

https://www.villagedescreateurs.com

content.title: Fourvière Basilica, the guardian angel

introduction.small: On the heights of the Fourvière hill, this emblematic monument overlooks the city. Lyon would not be Lyon without this basilica watching over her.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Fourvière Basilica, the guardian angel

paragraphs.text:
The Notre-Dame de Fourvière Basilica was built at the end of the 19th century in a neo-Byzantine style on the site of Trajan's ancient Forum, at the top of what the Lyonnais call "the hill that prays". Its architect, Pierre Bossan (1814-1888) wanted to express the greatness of faith. With its four towers and carved walls, the Basilica resembles a fortress and symbolises the unwavering faith of the Virgin Mary.

Inside, two superimposed churches reveal gold and lighting entirely devoted to the Virgin, giving Lyon its status as Mary's city. Every year, more than 2.5 million pilgrims and visitors climb to the top of the hill to discover the basilica, taking the "Ficelle", the funicular linking Old Lyon to the heights of the city. Alternately, the bravest travel up by foot. On December 8th, a torchlit procession leaves from the Place Saint-Jean below to reach the square in front of the basilica and celebrate the feast of the Immaculate Conception.

Basilique Notre-Dame de Fourvière
8 place de Fourvière
69005 Lyon

+33 (0)4 78 25 86 19

https://en.lyon-france.com/discover-lyon/heritage-unesco/Religious-heritage/basilica-of-fourviere

content.title: CLIMATE AND WEATHER IN Lyon
content.introduction: Lyon has a temperate continental climate. Winters tend to be cold and dry, while summers are hot and humid, punctuated by occasionally violent thunderstorms. Temperatures can rise above 35°C (95°F) on some days in the summer. In Lyon, it rains more during the summer than during the winter.

airports.title: Lyon Saint-Exupéry Airport
airports.description:
The Lyon Saint-Exupéry Airport is located 25km (16 miles) east of the city centre.
  • Two terminals:
    • Terminal 1
    • Terminal 2 (Air France)

Getting from the airport to Lyon and back:
  • By car
    • Accessible via the A432 and A43 motorways, about 30 minutes to the city centre.
    • Several parking facilities are available:

- P0 and P1 covered carparks: EUR 5.50 for the first 15 minutes, then EUR 7.50 for 15-30 minutes, EUR 9.50 for 30-45 minutes, EUR 11.50 for 45 minutes-1 hour, EUR 25.10 for 12 hours and EUR 28 for 24 hours.

- P2 nearby carpark: EUR 5.50 for the first 15 minutes, then EUR 7.50 for 15-30 minutes, EUR 8.50 for 30-45 minutes, EUR 9.50 for 45 minutes-1 hour, EUR 22.50 for 12 hours and EUR 25 for 24 hours.

- P4 nearby carpark: EUR 4.40 for the first 15 minutes, then EUR 6.40 for 15-30 minutes, EUR 7.40 for 30-45 minutes, EUR 8.40 for 45 minutes-1 hour, EUR 20.40 for 12 hours and EUR 22 for 24 hours.

- P5 budget carpark: EUR 4 for the first 15 minutes, then EUR 6 for 15-30 minutes, EUR 7 for 30-45 minutes, EUR 8 for 45 minutes-1 hour, EUR 20 for 12 hours and EUR 22 for 24 hours.
    • Several car rental companies have counters at the airport.
  • By taxi
    • There are taxi ranks outside Terminals 1 and 2 as well as the TGV train station.
    • Daytime fares to Lyon city centre are about EUR 50-55 (EUR 65-70 at night).
  • By rail
    • The Lyon-Saint Exupéry TGV train station is just a five-minute walk from terminals 1 and 2.
  • By tram
    • Rhônexpress: located a few minutes' walk from terminals 1 and 2, this tramway connects the Lyon Part-Dieu TGV station with the Lyon Saint-Exupéry airport, every day from 4:25 a.m. to midnight with a travel time of 30 minutes (EUR 15.20 one way, EUR 26.70 round trip). Trains depart every 20-30 minutes.
  • Services: shops, bars and restaurants, pharmacy, post office, currency exchange, etc.
  • Telephone: 0 826 800 826 (EUR 0.15/min)
  • Website: https://www.lyonaeroports.com/en/
  • Train + Air Service
  • Customers with a Paris connection and an Air France flight number (either from Orly or Charles de Gaulle) must visit the Train+Air desk at Lyon Part-Dieu station 24 hours to 20 minutes before their train's departure time to collect their train ticket: they will need to present a valid plane ticket to do so.
  • You will find all the information you need at https://www.airfrance.fr/FR/en/common/resainfovol/avion_train/reservation_avion_train_tgvair_airfrance.htm
  • The Lyon Part-Dieu TGV station is located at 5 Place Charles Béraudier, 69003 Lyon. It is open every day from 4.50 a.m. to 12.45 a.m. From the station, you can access:
    - public transport: tramway (Rhoneexpress lines T1, T3 and T4), intercity buses (lines 165, 1980, 2960 and 1920), subway (line B), city buses (lines C1, C2, C3, C6, C7, C9, C13, C25, 25, 37, 38 and 70).
    - private transport: drop off area, self-service car sharing, car rental companies, taxis, parking facilities, bike hire companies.

To find out everything you need to know about the Train+Air desk, please visit: https://www.garesetconnexions.sncf/fr/gare/frlpd/lyon-part-dieu/services/guichet-tgv-air

medical.title: Medical information
medical.description:
In order to travel in the best conditions and for your health and safety, we invite you to check all information regarding preventive measures and best practices to be respected, available on the official website of the French Ministry of Foreign Affairs: https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus

Your comfort, well-being and health are at the heart of Air France's concerns, and we want to help you prepare for your trip in the best way possible. Find out more about the measures taken to ensure safe travelling on our website: https://www.airfrance.fr/FR/en/common/page_flottante/information/coronavirus.htm#notre-engagement-sanitaire

See your doctor before you travel. It is also recommended to take out insurance covering medical expenses and repatriation before your trip. Lyon counts several hospitals and medical institutions, as well as quality medical practitioners and health specialists.

localCalendar.title: FESTIVALS, HOLIDAYS AND OTHER ANNUAL EVENTS IN Lyon
localCalendar.description: There are a number of festivals, holidays and other events celebrated in Lyon each year. The main ones are listed below.

events.title: March or April: Easter Monday (national holiday)
May 1: Labour Day (national holiday)
events.description: On the first of May, it is customary to offer a sprig of lily-of-the-valley to close ones. Many vendors occupy the pavement on that occasion!

events.title: May 8 : Victory Day (national holiday)
events.description: Commemorates the Allied victory in Europe that ended World War II on this day in 1945. Various ceremonies are held around town.

events.title: June 21: Fête de la Musique (celebrated nationwide)
events.description: Also celebrated internationally as World Music Day, for this festival many free concerts featuring all types of music are held in the streets and parks across Lyon. Festive and friendly atmosphere guaranteed!

events.title: July 14: Bastille Day (national holiday)
events.description: This holiday celebrates the storming of the Bastille prison in 1789, the key event marking the beginning of the French Revolution, and symbolises the end of the privileges enjoyed by the clergy and the aristocracy. In Lyon, a dance party open to everyone is held on the left bank of the Saône (between the Maréchal Juin and Bonaparte bridges) and a traditional fireworks display is set off from Fourvière hill at nightfall.

events.title: August 15: Assumption Day (national holiday)
events.description: This celebration, still very popular in Lyon, is marked by the faithful with religious processions and ceremonies through the streets. On this occasion, a fireworks display is set off from the Fourvière hill.

events.title: 3rd weekend in September: European Heritage Days (celebrated nationwide)
events.description: The aim of the European Heritage Days is to open up numerous sites and monuments, many of which are normally closed to the public, such as castles and private collections. A great opportunity for a lovely stroll through the city to admire architectural treasures!

events.title: November 11 : Remembrance Day (national holiday)
events.description: On this day, citizens gather at the war memorial in Lyon to commemorate the signing of the 1918 armistice officially bringing an end to the First World War.

events.title: Four days around December 8: Fête des Lumières (local event)
events.description: Known for centuries as a city of light, Lyon has hosted its Festival of Light for more than 150 years. First held on 8 December 1852 to celebrate the Virgin Mary, the festival was initially celebrated throughout the city by people lighting candles in their windows on 8 December. Nowadays the festival lasts four days, during which time dozens of sites are illuminated around the city, Artists from all around the world take part in this spectacular show, which attracts millions of visitors every year.

events.title: December 31 : New Year's Eve (national event)
events.description: On the night of December 31<sup>st</sup>, the atmosphere is particularly festive on the streets of Lyon, with families and friends celebrating the new year.

goodToKnow.tips:
Tipping
In Lyon like elsewhere in France, a service charge is always included in the bill. If you are particularly pleased with the service, you may certainly leave a few extra euros on the table. But this additional tip is neither expected nor necessary.
